skill.name: unity-editor
skill.description: Remote control Unity Editor via CLI using unityctl. Use when working with Unity projects to launch/stop editor, enter/exit play mode, compile scripts, view logs, load scenes, run tests, capture screenshots, or execute C# code for debugging. Activate when user mentions Unity, play mode, compilation, or needs to interact with a running Unity Editor.

security_audit.summary: The skill enables remote control of Unity Editor through a local bridge daemon. While it requires external command execution and network communication, these capabilities are necessary for its stated purpose. The tool binds only to localhost and doesn't expose remote access by default.

medium_findings.title: Arbitrary C# Code Execution
medium_findings.description: The skill allows execution of arbitrary C# code in Unity Editor through 'unityctl script execute' command. While this is documented functionality for debugging, it could be misused to execute malicious code within the Unity environment.

low_findings.title: Local Network Communication
low_findings.description: The tool uses HTTP and WebSocket connections on localhost for communication between CLI, bridge daemon, and Unity Editor. While this is necessary for functionality, it represents a network attack surface.

content.user_title: Control Unity Editor from command line
content.value_statement: Stop switching between Unity Editor and terminal when developing games. This skill lets AI agents control Unity directly from the command line to compile scripts, enter play mode, capture screenshots, and execute debug code.
actual_capabilities: Launch and stop Unity Editor from command line
Compile C# scripts and view compilation errors
Enter/exit play mode without using mouse
Execute arbitrary C# code in editor for debugging
limitations: Requires Unity Editor with unityctl plugin installed
Bridge daemon must be running before using commands
Only works with local Unity instances (no remote control)
C# script execution requires specific method signature

use_cases.title: Debug without editor context switching

use_cases.title: Automate Unity editor workflows
use_cases.description: Script entire Unity workflows including compilation, play mode testing, and screenshot capture for CI/CD pipelines.

best_practices: Always run 'unityctl status' first to verify bridge and editor are connected
Use 'unityctl asset refresh' after modifying scripts before entering play mode
Write complex C# scripts to files and execute with -f flag for better debugging
anti_patterns: Don't execute untrusted C# code from unknown sources in your Unity editor
Avoid running multiple bridge instances for the same project
Don't rely on this for production builds - use Unity's batch mode instead

faq.question: Which Unity versions are compatible?
faq.answer: Unity 6.0 and later versions with netstandard2.1 support. The tool auto-detects your Unity installation.

faq.question: Is there a limit to how many commands I can run?
faq.answer: No hard limits, but the bridge maintains a 1000-entry log buffer. Commands timeout after 30 seconds by default.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my CI/CD pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, the CLI returns appropriate exit codes and supports JSON output format for automation scripts.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this tool?
faq.answer: All communication happens locally on your machine. The bridge only binds to localhost and doesn't expose remote access.

faq.question: What if the connection to Unity is lost?
faq.answer: The bridge automatically reconnects after Unity domain reloads. Use 'unityctl status' to check connection health.

faq.question: How does this compare to Unity's batch mode?
faq.answer: Unlike batch mode, this works while Unity Editor is open, providing visual feedback and interactive debugging capabilities.
